gold: : a yellow metallic element that occurs naturally in pure form and is used especially in coins, jewelry, and electronics  — see Chemical Elements Table
grass: : herbage suitable or used for grazing animals
parrot: : any of numerous widely distributed tropical birds (order Psittaciformes and especially family Psittacidae) that are often crested and brightly colored, have a distinctive stout hooked bill and zygodactyl feet, and include some excellent mimics
afternoon: : the part of day between noon and sunset
greece: country in southern Europe comprised of a jagged peninsula at the southern end of the Balkan Peninsula and several hundred islands in the Aegean and Ionian seas; with a prominent history dating to ancient times, today it is a republic with its capital at Athens area 50,949 square miles (131,957 square kilometers), population 10,762,000
airport: : a place from which aircraft operate that usually has paved runways and maintenance facilities and often serves as a terminal
guitar: : a flat-bodied stringed instrument with a long fretted neck and usually six strings played with a pick or with the fingers
ambulance: : a vehicle equipped for transporting the injured or sick
hair: : a slender threadlike outgrowth of the epidermis of an animal
pillow: : a support for the head of a reclining person
animal: : a living thing that is not a human being or plant
pizza: : a dish made typically of flattened bread dough spread with a savory mixture usually including tomatoes and cheese and often other toppings and baked
answer: : something spoken or written in reply to a question
helicopter: : an aircraft whose lift is derived from the aerodynamic forces acting on one or more powered rotors turning about substantially vertical axes
planet: : any of the large bodies that revolve around the sun in the solar system
apple: : the fleshy, usually rounded red, yellow, or green edible pome fruit of a usually cultivated tree (genus Malus) of the rose family
helmet: : a covering or enclosing headpiece of ancient or medieval armor  — see armor illustration
army: : a large organized body of armed personnel trained for war especially on land
portugal: country in southwestern Europe in the western Iberian Peninsula bordering on the Atlantic Ocean; a kingdom before 1910; now a republic; capital Lisbon area (not including the Azores and Madeira) 35,383 square miles (91,642 square kilometers), population 10,355,000
australia: continent of the eastern hemisphere southeast of Asia and south of the Equator area 2,948,366 square miles (7,665,751 square kilometers)
honey: : a sweet viscid material elaborated out of the nectar of flowers in the honey sac of various bees
balloon: : a nonporous bag of light material that can be inflated especially with air or gas: such as
horse: : a large solid-hoofed herbivorous ungulate mammal (Equus caballus, family Equidae, the horse family) domesticated since prehistoric times and used as a beast of burden, a draft animal, or for riding
queen: : the wife or widow of a king
banana: : an elongated usually tapering tropical fruit with soft pulpy flesh enclosed in a soft usually yellow rind
hospital: : a charitable institution for the needy, aged, infirm, or young
quill: : a bobbin, spool, or spindle on which filling yarn is wound
battery: : the act of beating someone or something with successive blows : the act of battering (see batter entry 1 sense 1)
house: : a building in which a family lives
rain: : water falling in drops condensed from vapor in the atmosphere
hydrogen: : a nonmetallic gaseous chemical element with atomic number 1 that is the simplest and lightest of the elements and that is used especially in the processing of fossil fuels and the synthesis of ammonia  — see Chemical Elements Table  — compare deuterium, tritium
rainbow: : an arc or circle that exhibits in concentric bands the colors of the spectrum and that is formed opposite the sun by the refraction and reflection of the sun's rays in raindrops, spray, or mist
beard: : the hair that grows on a man's face often excluding the mustache
bed: : a piece of furniture on or in which to lie and sleep
insect: : any of a class (Insecta) of arthropods (such as bugs or bees) with well-defined head, thorax, and abdomen, only three pairs of legs, and typically one or two pairs of wings
belgium: country of western Europe bordering on the North Sea and comprising the Dutch-speaking region of Flanders and the French-speaking region of Wallonia; a constitutional monarchy; capital Brussels area 11,787 square miles (30,528 square kilometers), population 11,571,000
insurance: : coverage by contract whereby one party undertakes to indemnify or guarantee another against loss by a specified contingency or peril
restaurant: : a business establishment where meals or refreshments may be purchased
boy: : a male child from birth to adulthood
iron: : a silver-white malleable ductile magnetic heavy metallic element that readily rusts in moist air, occurs in pure form in meteorites and combined in most igneous rocks, is the most abundant element on Earth by mass, and is vital to biological processes  — see Chemical Elements Table
river: : a natural stream of water of usually considerable volume
branch: : a natural subdivision of a plant stem
island: : a tract of land surrounded by water and smaller than a continent
rocket: : any of several plants of the mustard family: such as
breakfast: : the first meal of the day especially when taken in the morning
jackal: : any of several small omnivorous canids (such as Canis aureus) of Africa and Asia having large ears, long legs, and bushy tails
room: : an extent of space occupied by or sufficient or available for something
brother: : a male who has the same parents as another or one parent in common with another
jelly: : a soft somewhat elastic food product made usually with gelatin or pectin
rose: : any of a genus (Rosa of the family Rosaceae, the rose family) of usually prickly shrubs with pinnate leaves and showy flowers having five petals in the wild state but being often double or partly double under cultivation
camera: : a device that consists of a lightproof chamber with an aperture fitted with a lens and a shutter through which the image of an object is projected onto a surface for recording (as on a photosensitive film or an electronic sensor) or for translation into electrical impulses (as for television broadcast)
jewellery: : ornamental pieces (such as rings, necklaces, earrings, and bracelets) that are made of materials which may or may not be precious (such as gold, silver, glass, and plastic), are often set with genuine or imitation gems, and are worn for personal adornment
russia: independent country in eastern Europe and northern Asia bordering on the Arctic and Pacific oceans and on the Baltic and Black seas and covering the largest area of any country in the world; capital Moscow area 6,601,668 square miles (17,098,242 square kilometers), population 142,123,000
candle: : a usually molded or dipped mass of wax or tallow containing a wick that may be burned (as to give light, heat, or scent or for celebration or votive purposes)
jordan: David Starr 1851–1931 American biologist and educator
sandwich: : two pieces of bread with something (such as meat, peanut butter, etc.) between them
car: : a vehicle moving on wheels: such as
juice: : the extractable fluid contents of cells or tissues
school: : an organization that provides instruction: such as
caravan: : a company of travelers on a journey through desert or hostile regions
kangaroo: : any of various herbivorous leaping marsupial mammals (family Macropodidae) of Australia, New Guinea, and adjacent islands with a small head, large ears, long powerful hind legs, a long thick tail used as a support and in balancing, and rather small forelegs not used in locomotion
scooter: : a vehicle ridden while standing that consists of a narrow footboard mounted between or atop two wheels tandem that has an upright steering handle attached to the front wheel, and that is moved by pushing with one foot
carpet: : a heavy often tufted fabric used as a floor covering
king: : a male ruler of a country who usually inherits his position and rules for life
cartoon: : a preparatory design, drawing, or painting (as for a fresco)
kitchen: : a place (such as a room) with cooking facilities
shoe: : an outer covering for the human foot typically having a thick or stiff sole with an attached heel and an upper part of lighter material (such as leather)
kite: : a light frame covered with paper, cloth, or plastic, often provided with a stabilizing tail, and designed to be flown in the air at the end of a long string
soccer: : a game played on a field between two teams of 11 players each with the object to propel a round ball into the opponent's goal by kicking or by hitting it with any part of the body except the hands and arms
church: : a building that is used for Christian religious services
knife: : a cutting instrument consisting of a sharp blade fastened to a handle
spoon: : an eating or cooking implement consisting of a small shallow bowl with a relatively long handle
crayon: : a stick of white or colored chalk or of colored wax used for writing or drawing
lamp: : any of various devices for producing light or sometimes heat: such as
stone: : a concretion of earthy or mineral matter:
lawyer: : one whose profession is to conduct lawsuits for clients or to advise as to legal rights and obligations in other matters
sugar: : a sweet crystallizable material that consists wholly or essentially of sucrose, is colorless or white when pure tending to brown when less refined, is obtained commercially from sugarcane or sugar beet and less extensively from sorghum, maples, and palms, and is important as a source of dietary carbohydrate and as a sweetener and preservative of other foods
daughter: : a female offspring especially of human parents
sweden: country (a kingdom) in northern Europe on the peninsula of Scandinavia west of the Baltic Sea; capital Stockholm area 173,860 square miles (450,295 square kilometers), population 10,041,000
death: : the end of life : the time when someone or something dies
library: : a place in which literary, musical, artistic, or reference materials (such as books, manuscripts, recordings, or films) are kept for use but not for sale
teacher: : a person or thing that teaches something
denmark: country of northern Europe occupying most of the Jutland Peninsula and adjacent islands in the Baltic and North seas; a kingdom; capital Copenhagen area 16,639 square miles (43,094 square kilometers), population 5,810,000
lighter: : a large usually flat-bottomed barge used especially in unloading or loading ships
telephone: : an instrument for reproducing sounds at a distance
diamond: : native crystalline carbon that is the hardest known mineral, that is usually nearly colorless, that when transparent and free from flaws is highly valued as a precious stone, and that is used industrially especially as an abrasive
lion: : a large heavily built social cat (Panthera leo) of open or rocky areas chiefly of sub-Saharan Africa though once widely distributed throughout Africa and southern Asia that has a tawny body with a tufted tail and a shaggy blackish or dark brown mane in the male
television: : an electronic system of transmitting transient images of fixed or moving objects together with sound over a wire or through space by apparatus that converts light and sound into electrical waves and reconverts them into visible light rays and audible sound
dinner: : the principal meal of the day
lizard: : any of a suborder (Lacertilia) of reptiles distinguished from the snakes by a fused inseparable lower jaw, a single temporal opening, two pairs of well differentiated functional limbs which may be lacking in burrowing forms, external ears, and eyes with movable lids
tent: : a collapsible shelter of fabric (such as nylon or canvas) stretched and sustained by poles and used for camping outdoors or as a temporary building
disease: : an illness that affects a person, animal, or plant : a condition that prevents the body or mind from working normally
lock: : a tuft, tress, or ringlet of hair
thailand: country (a kingdom) in southeastern Asia on the Gulf of Thailand and the Andaman Sea; capital Bangkok area 198,117 square miles (513,120 square kilometers), population 68,616,000
doctor: : a person who is skilled in the science of medicine : a person who is trained and licensed to treat sick and injured people
london: John Griffith 1876–1916 Jack London American writer
tomato: : the usually large, rounded, edible, pulpy berry of an herb (genus Solanum) of the nightshade family native to South America that is typically red but may be yellow, orange, green, or purplish in color and is eaten raw or cooked as a vegetable
toothbrush: : a brush for cleaning the teeth
dream: : a series of thoughts, images, or emotions occurring during sleep
machine: : a mechanically, electrically, or electronically operated device for performing a task
traffic: : the vehicles, pedestrians, ships, or planes moving along a route
magazine: : a print periodical containing miscellaneous pieces (such as articles, stories, poems) and often illustrated
train: : a connected line of railroad cars with or without a locomotive
easter: : a feast that commemorates Christ's resurrection and is observed with variations of date due to different calendars on the first Sunday after the paschal full moon
truck: : a wheeled vehicle for moving heavy articles: such as
egg: : the hard-shelled reproductive body produced by a bird and especially by the common domestic chicken
manchester: city in northwestern England east-northeast of Liverpool made accessible to the Irish Sea
uganda: republic in eastern Africa north of Lake Victoria capital Kampala area 93,065 square miles (241,038 square kilometers), population 40,854,000
eggplant: : a widely cultivated perennial Asian herb (Solanum melongena) of the nightshade family yielding edible fruit
market: : a meeting together of people for the purpose of trade by private purchase and sale and usually not by auction
umbrella: : a collapsible shade for protection against weather consisting of fabric stretched over hinged ribs radiating from a central pole
egypt: country of northeastern Africa bordering on the Mediterranean and Red seas and site of an early and long enduring civilization of the ancient world; capital Cairo area 386,662 square miles (1,001,450 square kilometers), population 99,413,000  — see united arab republic
match: : a person or thing equal or similar to another
van: : a usually enclosed wagon or motortruck used for transportation of goods or animals
elephant: : a thickset, usually extremely large, nearly hairless, herbivorous mammal (family Elephantidae, the elephant family) that has a snout elongated into a muscular trunk and two incisors in the upper jaw developed especially in the male into long ivory tusks:
microphone: : an instrument whereby sound waves are caused to generate or modulate an electric current usually for the purpose of transmitting or recording sound (such as speech or music)
vase: : a usually round vessel of greater depth than width used chiefly as an ornament or for holding flowers
energy: : ability to be active : the physical or mental strength that allows you to do things
monkey: : a nonhuman primate mammal with the exception usually of the lemurs and tarsiers
vegetable: : a usually herbaceous plant (such as the cabbage, bean, or potato) grown for an edible part that is usually eaten as part of a meal
engine: : a machine for converting any of various forms of energy into mechanical force and motion
vulture: : any of various large birds (families Accipitridae and Cathartidae) that are related to the hawks, eagles, and falcons but have weaker claws and the head usually naked and that subsist chiefly or entirely on carrion
england: country of southern Great Britain; a division of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland; capital London area 50,333 square miles (130,362 square kilometers), population 53,012,456
motorcycle: : an automotive vehicle with two in-line wheels
wall: : a high thick masonry structure forming a long rampart or an enclosure chiefly for defense
evening: : the latter part and close of the day and early part of the night
nail: : a horny sheath protecting the upper end of each finger and toe of humans and most other primates
whale: : any of various very large, aquatic, marine mammals (order Cetacea) that have a torpedo-shaped body with a thick layer of blubber, paddle-shaped forelimbs but no hind limbs, a horizontally flattened tail, and nostrils that open externally at the top of the head
eye: : a specialized light-sensitive sensory structure of animals that in nearly all vertebrates, most arthropods, and some mollusks is the image-forming organ of sight
napkin: : a piece of material (such as cloth or paper) used at table to wipe the lips or fingers and protect the clothes
window: : an opening especially in the wall of a building for admission of light and air that is usually closed by casements or sashes containing transparent material (such as glass) and capable of being opened and shut
family: : a group of people who are related to each other
needle: : a small slender usually steel instrument that has an eye for thread or surgical sutures at one end and that is used for sewing
wire: : metal in the form of a usually very flexible thread or slender rod
finland: country of northern Europe bordering on the Gulf of Bothnia and the Gulf of Finland and extending north of the Arctic Circle; a republic with its capital at Helsinki area 130,559 square miles (338,145 square kilometers), population 5,537,000
nest: : a bed or receptacle prepared by an animal and especially a bird for its eggs and young
xylophone: : a percussion instrument consisting of a series of wooden bars graduated in length to produce the musical scale, supported on belts of straw or felt, and sounded by striking with two small wooden hammers
nigeria: country in western Africa which borders on the Gulf of Guinea, is a republic within the Commonwealth of Nations, and was formerly a colony and protectorate; capital Abuja area 356,669 square miles (923,768 square kilometers), population 203,453,000
yacht: : any of various recreational watercraft: such as
flag: : any of various monocotyledonous plants with long ensiform leaves: such as
night: : the time from dusk to dawn when no sunlight is visible
yak: : a large long-haired wild or domesticated ox (Bos grunniens synonym B. mutus) of Tibet and adjacent elevated parts of central Asia
flower: : the specialized part of an angiospermous plant that occurs singly or in clusters, possesses whorls of often colorful petals or sepals, and bears the reproductive structures (such as stamens or pistils) involved in the development of seeds and fruit : blossom
notebook: : a book for notes or memoranda
zebra: : any of several swift African mammals (Equus grevyi, E. quagga synonym E. burchelli, and E. zebra) related to the horse but distinctively and conspicuously patterned in stripes of black or dark brown and white or buff
football: : any of several games played between two teams on a usually rectangular field having goalposts or goals at each end and whose object is to get the ball over a goal line, into a goal, or between goalposts by running, passing, or kicking: such as
ocean: : the whole body of salt water that covers nearly three fourths of the surface of the earth
zoo: : a place where many kinds of animals are kept so that people can see them
forest: : a dense growth of trees and underbrush covering a large tract
oil: : any of numerous unctuous combustible substances that are liquid or can be liquefied easily on warming, are soluble in ether but not in water, and leave a greasy stain on paper or cloth
garden: : a plot of ground where herbs, fruits, flowers, or vegetables are cultivated
fountain: : the source from which something proceeds or is supplied
orange: : a globose berry with a yellowish to reddish-orange rind and a sweet edible pulp
gas: : a fluid (such as air) that has neither independent shape nor volume but tends to expand indefinitely
france: Anatole 1844–1924 pseudonym of Jacques-Anatole-François Thibault French novelist and satirist
oxygen: : a chemical element that constitutes 21 percent of the Earth's atmosphere, that is capable of combining with all elements except some noble gases, that is active in physiological processes of almost all known organisms, and that is involved especially in combustion  — see Chemical Elements Table
girl: : a female child from birth to adulthood
furniture: : equipment that is necessary, useful, or desirable: such as
oyster: : any of various marine bivalve mollusks (family Ostreidae) that have a rough irregular shell closed by a single adductor muscle and include commercially important shellfish
glass: : any of various amorphous materials formed from a melt by cooling to rigidity without crystallization: such as
garage: : a shelter or repair shop for automotive vehicles
ghost: : the seat of life or intelligence : soul
abnormally: : deviating from the normal or average
abruptly: : in an abrupt manner : in a sudden and unexpected way
absently: : not present at a usual or expected place : missing
accidentally: : in an accidental or unintended manner : by accident
accusingly: : to charge with a fault or offense : blame
actually: : in act or in fact : really
adventurously: : disposed to seek adventure or to cope with the new and unknown
adversely: : in an adverse manner : in a way that is bad or harmful
afterwards: : at a later or succeeding time : subsequently, thereafter
almost: : very nearly but not exactly or entirely
anxiously: : characterized by extreme uneasiness of mind or brooding fear about some contingency : worried
arrogantly: : exaggerating or disposed to exaggerate one's own worth or importance often by an overbearing manner
awkwardly: : lacking dexterity or skill (as in the use of hands)
bashfully: : socially shy or timid : diffident, self-conscious
beautifully: : in a beautiful manner : in a way that excites aesthetic pleasure
bitterly: : being, inducing, or marked by the one of the five basic taste sensations that is peculiarly acrid, astringent, and often disagreeable and characteristic of citrus peels, unsweetened cocoa, black coffee, mature leafy greens (such as kale or mustard), or ale
bleakly: : exposed and barren and often windswept
blissfully: : full of, marked by, or causing complete happiness
bravely: : feeling or showing no fear : not afraid
brightly: : radiating or reflecting light : shining, sparkling
broadly: : having ample extent from side to side or between limits
calmly: : a quiet and peaceful state or condition
carefully: : marked by wary caution or prudence
cautiously: : careful about avoiding danger or risk
certainly: : in a manner that is certain : with certainty
cleverly: : intelligent and able to learn things quickly
closely: : to move so as to bar passage through something
commonly: : of or relating to a community at large : public
continually: : in a continual manner : without stopping or interruption
correctly: : to make or set right : amend
courageously: : very brave : having or showing courage
crossly: : a long piece of wood with a shorter piece across it near the top that people were once fastened to and left to die on as a form of punishment
cruelly: : disposed to inflict pain or suffering : devoid of humane feelings
daily: : occurring, made, or acted upon every day
daringly: : venturesomely bold in action or thought

equally: : in an equal or uniform manner : evenly
eventually: : at an unspecified later time : in the end
exactly: : in a manner or measure or to a degree or number that strictly conforms to a fact or condition

fast: : moving or able to move quickly

fully: : in a full manner or degree : completely

innocently: : free from legal guilt or fault
inwardly: : in the innermost being : mentally, spiritually

mortally: : in a deadly or fatal manner : to death
mysteriously: : in a mysterious manner : in a way that is difficult to explain or comprehend
naturally: : by nature : by natural character or ability

poorly: : in a poor condition or manner

searchingly: : to look into or over carefully or thoroughly in an effort to find or discover something: such as

swiftly: : in a swift manner : with speed : quickly
sympathetically: : existing or operating through an affinity, interdependence, or mutual association

uselessly: : having or being of no use:

adventurous: : disposed to seek adventure or to cope with the new and unknown
agreeable: : pleasing to the mind or senses especially as according well with one's tastes or needs
alert: : watchful and prompt to meet danger or emergency
alive: : having life : not dead or inanimate
amused: : pleasantly entertained or diverted (as by something funny)
annoying: : causing vexation or irritation : causing annoyance : irritating
anxious: : characterized by extreme uneasiness of mind or brooding fear about some contingency : worried
arrogant: : exaggerating or disposed to exaggerate one's own worth or importance often by an overbearing manner
average: : a number that is calculated by adding quantities together and then dividing the total by the number of quantities
bad: : failing to reach an acceptable standard : poor
beautiful: : having qualities of beauty : exciting aesthetic pleasure
bewildered: : deeply or utterly confused or perplexed
black: : having the very dark color of the night sky or the eye's pupil : of the color black (see black entry 2 sense 2)
bloody: : containing or made up of blood
blue: : of the color whose hue is that of the clear sky : of the color blue (see blue entry 2 sense 1)
bored: : filled with or characterized by boredom
brainy: : having or showing a well-developed intellect : intelligent
brave: : feeling or showing no fear : not afraid
bright: : radiating or reflecting light : shining, sparkling
calm: : a quiet and peaceful state or condition
careful: : marked by wary caution or prudence
cautious: : careful about avoiding danger or risk
clever: : intelligent and able to learn things quickly
cloudy: : of, relating to, or resembling cloud
combative: : marked by eagerness to fight or contend
comfortable: : affording or enjoying contentment and security

courageous: : very brave : having or showing courage
crazy: : having or showing severe mental illness
crowded: : filled with many or too many people or things

curious: : marked by desire to investigate and learn
cute: : having a pleasing and usually youthful appearance
dangerous: : involving possible injury, pain, harm, or loss : characterized by danger
dark: : devoid or partially devoid of light : not receiving, reflecting, transmitting, or radiating light
dead: : deprived of life : no longer alive
defiant: : full of or showing a disposition to challenge, resist, or fight : full of or showing defiance : bold, impudent
determined: : having reached a decision : firmly resolved
different: : not of the same kind : partly or totally unlike
difficult: : hard to do, make, or carry out : arduous
disgusted: : feeling or showing disgust : disturbed physically or mentally by something distasteful
distinct: : distinguishable to the eye or mind as being discrete (see discrete sense 1) or not the same : separate
disturbed: : experiencing or exhibiting emotional disturbance or agitation : having a mental disability or illness
doubtful: : lacking a definite opinion, conviction, or determination
eager: : marked by enthusiastic or impatient desire or interest
easy: : causing or involving little difficulty or discomfort
embarrassed: : feeling or showing a state of self-conscious confusion and distress
enchanting: : powerfully pleasing, appealing, or delightful : charming
energetic: : operating with or marked by vigor or effect
enthusiastic: : filled with or marked by enthusiasm
excited: : having, showing, or characterized by a heightened state of energy, enthusiasm, eagerness, etc. : feeling or showing excitement
fair: : marked by impartiality and honesty : free from self-interest, prejudice, or favoritism
faithful: : steadfast in affection or allegiance : loyal
fancy: : to have a fancy (see fancy entry 2 sense 1) for : like
fantastic: : based on fantasy (see fantasy entry 1 sense 2) : not real
fierce: : violently hostile or aggressive in temperament
filthy: : covered with, containing, or characterized by filth
foolish: : having or showing a lack of good sense, judgment, or discretion
friendly: : of, relating to, or befitting a friend: such as
frightened: : feeling fear : made to feel afraid
gentle: : free from harshness, sternness, or violence
gleaming: : a transient appearance of subdued or partly obscured light
gorgeous: : splendidly or showily brilliant or magnificent
graceful: : displaying grace (see grace entry 1 sense 3) in form or action : pleasing or attractive in line, proportion, or movement
grotesque: : a style of decorative art characterized by fanciful or fantastic human and animal forms often interwoven with foliage or similar figures that may distort the natural into absurdity, ugliness, or caricature
handsome: : having a pleasing and usually impressive or dignified appearance
happy: : feeling pleasure and enjoyment because of your life, situation, etc.
homeless: : having no home or permanent place of residence
homely: : suggestive or characteristic of a place of residence or home
horrible: : marked by or arousing painful and intense fear, dread, dismay, or aversion : marked by or arousing horror
hungry: : feeling an uneasy or painful sensation from lack of food : feeling hunger
hurt: : to inflict with physical pain : wound
important: : marked by or indicative of significant worth or consequence : valuable in content or relationship
impossible: : incapable of being or of occurring
innocent: : free from legal guilt or fault
jealous: : feeling or showing an unhappy or angry desire to have what someone else has
kind: : a group united by common traits or interests : category
lazy: : disinclined to activity or exertion : not energetic or vigorous
lovely: : delightful for beauty, harmony, or grace : attractive
magnificent: : great in deed or exalted in place
modern: : of, relating to, or characteristic of the present or the immediate past : contemporary
motionless: : an act, process, or instance of changing place : movement
mushy: : having the consistency of mush : soft
mysterious: : of, relating to, or constituting mystery
nice: : giving pleasure or joy : good and enjoyable
obedient: : submissive to the restraint or command of authority : willing to obey
obnoxious: : odiously or disgustingly objectionable : highly offensive
odd: : differing markedly from the usual, ordinary, or accepted : peculiar
old-fashioned: : of, relating to, or characteristic of a past era
open: : having no enclosing or confining barrier : accessible on all or nearly all sides
outrageous: : exceeding the limits of what is usual
panicky: : of, relating to, or resembling the mental or emotional state believed induced by the god Pan
perfect: : being entirely without fault or defect : flawless

powerful: : having great power, prestige, or influence
precious: : rare and worth a lot of money
prickly: : full of or covered with prickles

quaint: : pleasingly or strikingly old-fashioned or unfamiliar

rich: : having abundant possessions and especially material wealth
selfish: : concerned excessively or exclusively with oneself : seeking or concentrating on one's own advantage, pleasure, or well-being without regard for others
silly: : exhibiting or indicative of a lack of common sense or sound judgment
smiling: : to have, produce, or exhibit a smile
smoggy: : characterized by or abounding in smog
splendid: : possessing or displaying splendor: such as

strange: : different from what is usual, ordinary, or expected : odd
successful: : having the correct or desired result : ending in success
talented: : a special often athletic, creative, or artistic aptitude
tame: : reduced from a state of native wildness especially so as to be tractable and useful to humans : domesticated
tasty: : having a marked and appetizing flavor
tender: : marked by, responding to, or expressing the softer emotions : fond, loving
tired: : drained of strength and energy : fatigued often to the point of exhaustion
tough: : difficult to accomplish, resolve, endure, or deal with
uninterested: : not interested : not having the mind or feelings engaged
unsightly: : not pleasing to the sight : not comely
upset: : to thicken and shorten (something, such as a heated bar of iron) by hammering on the end : swage
vast: : very great in size, amount, degree, intensity, or especially in extent or range
vivacious: : lively in temper, conduct, or spirit : sprightly
wandering: : characterized by aimless, slow, or pointless movement: such as
weary: : exhausted in strength, endurance, vigor, or freshness
wide-eyed: : having or marked by unsophisticated or uncritical acceptance or admiration : naive
wild: : living in a state of nature and not ordinarily tame or domesticated
witty: : marked by or full of clever humor or wit : smartly facetious or jocular
worried: : mentally troubled or concerned : feeling or showing concern or anxiety about what is happening or might happen
wrong: : an injurious, unfair, or unjust act : action or conduct inflicting harm without due provocation or just cause
zany: : very eccentric (see eccentric entry 1 sense 1a) or absurd (see absurd entry 1 sense 1) often in an amusing way
zealous: : marked by fervent partisanship for a person, a cause, or an ideal : filled with or characterized by zeal
been: : to equal in meaning : have the same connotation as : symbolize
done: : arrived at or brought to an end
thought: : something that is thought: such as

came: : a slender grooved lead rod used to hold together panes of glass especially in a stained-glass window
looked: : to make sure or take care (that something is done)
found: : having all usual, standard, or reasonably expected equipment
worked: : that has been subjected to some process of development, treatment, or manufacture
called: : to speak in a loud voice
tried: : found good, faithful, or trustworthy through experience or testing
asked: : to call on for an answer
felt: : a cloth made of wool and fur often mixed with natural or synthetic fibers through the action of heat, moisture, chemicals, and pressure
left: : of, relating to, situated on, or being the side of the body in which the heart is mostly located
put: : to place in a specified position or relationship : lay
began: : to do the first part of an action : go into the first part of a process : start
begun: : to do the first part of an action : go into the first part of a process : start
seemed: : to appear to the observation or understanding
helped: : to give assistance or support to
talked: : to express or exchange ideas by means of spoken words
turned: : to cause to move around an axis or a center : make rotate or revolve
started: : to move suddenly and violently : spring
showed: : to cause or permit to be seen : exhibit
shown: : to cause or permit to be seen : exhibit
heard: island in the southern Indian Ocean southeast of Kerguelen at 53°10′ south, 74°10′ east; administered by Australia
played: : a piece of writing that tells a story through the actions and words of characters and that is performed on a stage
run: : to move with your legs at a speed that is faster than walking
moved: : to go or pass to another place or in a certain direction with a continuous motion
liked: : to enjoy (something) : to get pleasure from (something)
believed: : to accept or regard (something) as true
wrote: : to form (characters, symbols, etc.) on a surface with an instrument (such as a pen)
provided: : on condition that : with the understanding : if
lost: : not made use of, won, or claimed
paid: : marked by the receipt of pay
included: : to take in or comprise as a part of a whole or group
set: : to cause to sit : place in or on a seat
learned: : characterized by or associated with learning : erudite
changed: : to make different in some particular : alter
led: : a semiconductor diode that emits light when a voltage is applied to it and that is used especially in electronic devices (as for an indicator light)
watched: : to keep vigil as a devotional exercise
followed: : to go, proceed, or come after
stopped: : to close by filling or obstructing
spoke: : any of the small radiating bars inserted in the hub of a wheel to support the rim
spoken: : delivered by word of mouth : oral
read: : to receive or take in the sense of (letters, symbols, etc.) especially by sight or touch
added: : existing or occurring as an increase or addition : additional, further
opened: : having no enclosing or confining barrier : accessible on all or nearly all sides
walked: : to move along on foot : advance by steps
won: the basic monetary unit of North Korea and South Korea  — see Money Table

loved: : a feeling of strong or constant affection for a person
appeared: : to be or come in sight
waited: : to stay in place in expectation of : await
died: : to pass from physical life : expire
sent: a former monetary subunit equal to ¹/₁₀₀ kroon

stayed: : a large strong rope usually of wire used to support a mast
fallen: : to come or go down quickly from a high place or position

killed: : being or containing a virus that has been inactivated (as by chemicals) so that it is no longer infectious
remained: : to be a part not destroyed, taken, or used up
suggested: : to mention or imply as a possibility
raised: : having a pattern or design projecting from a background : done in relief
required: : stipulated as necessary to be done, made, or provided
reported: : a story in a newspaper or on radio or television that is about something that happened or that gives information about something
